awd_titl_txt: PIRE Investigation of Multi-Scale, Multi-Phase Phenomena in Complex Fluids for the Energy Industries
awd_abstract_narration:
Masahiro Kawaji (PI), Sanjoy  Banerjee, Robert Messinger, Jeffrey Morris, Vincent Pauchard (CUNY City College)

Multi-phase fluid flows involving mixtures of liquids, and often solids and gases as well, play an important role in nature and in the environment. Research on multi-phase flows is important to many key energy technologies, including oil-gas production and processing, energy conversion and storage, refrigeration and heating/cooling systems. This PIRE project will investigate microscopic phenomena occurring in complex liquid-liquid, multi-phase systems. The collaborative research will result in innovations in both experimental and modeling methods, leading to improvements in energy and process efficiency in industrial systems. It will also accelerate education and training of students and early career researchers by providing them unique opportunities participate in substantive international research experiences, taking advantage of the scope, scale, expertise, and facilities of the PIRE network. The City College of New York (CCNY) will collaborate with eleven international partner institutions, three in Norway, and four each in France and Germany. Partners will contribute both expertise and research tools that are complementary to those available at CCNY. The resources and research infrastructure will be shared to build strong international partnerships and enable research advances in multi-phase fluids that could not occur otherwise. The research and education plans will ensure that the U.S. maintains its competitive status in the field of complex, multi-phase fluids and their applications to engineering systems.


This PIRE project includes four research thrusts wherein microscopic-scale insight into molecular and interfacial control of transport phenomena would result in transformative improvements in commercial-scale energy processes: asphaltenes, gas hydrates, drilling fluids, and phase-change nano-emulsions, with diverse applications in oil & gas, thermal energy storage, and environmentally friendly refrigeration. The critical common issue in the four research thrusts is that molecular-scale phenomena, particularly at interfaces, impact macro-scale properties and behavior. Through experiments and theoretical/numerical analyses, the overarching objectives of this project are to (i) elucidate molecular-level phenomena that govern the formation, aggregation and stability of interfacial and network structures in multi-phase systems, and (ii) control their development and effects on macro-scale rheology and transport processes. Challenging fundamental issues will be addressed related to interfacial adsorption and/or crystallization processes by network-forming species or particles, which can form bridges between dispersed phases and dramatically affect macroscopic fluid behavior, e.g., transitions from fluid to gel-like systems or heat and mass transfer instabilities. Resolution of these problems could transform the ability to efficiently use, transport, and control complex, multi-phase fluids, which include liquids with other immiscible and dispersed liquid, gas, and/or solid phases. To address these issues, cross-cutting research approaches available at CCNY and international partner institutions will be used, e.g., from nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, density functional theory (DFT) and molecular dynamics (MD) at the molecular scale, to X-ray tomography, X-ray particle tracking velocimetry, rheological measurements and Lattice Boltzmann (LB) simulations at the micro- and macro-scales. Using cutting-edge experimental and theoretical research techniques that probe physicochemical phenomena up from the atomic length scale, the proposed project will transform existing understanding of multi-phase fluids while incorporating a unique set of non-intrusive, radiation-based techniques with wavelengths ranging from radiofrequencies to gamma-ray frequencies (e.g., high resolution tomography).

Project Title: PIRE: Multi-scale, Multi-phase Phenomena in Complex Fluids for the Energy Industries   

Project Duration: 5 years + 2 year No Cost Extension

Total Budget: $5.2 million

Lead Institution: The City University of New York (CUNY) - City College of New York (CCNY)

Principal Investigators:

         PI: Masahiro Kawaji (Prof. of Mechanical Engineering; Associate Director, CUNY Energy Institute)

          Co-PI: Sanjoy Banerjee (Distinguished Prof. of Chem. Eng.; Director, CUNY Energy Institute)
          Co-PI: Robert Messinger (Associate Prof. of Chemical Engineering; CUNY Energy Institute)
          Co-PI: Jeff Morris (Prof. of Chemical Engineering; Director, Levich Institute)
          Co-PI: Taehun Lee (Prof. of Mechanical Engineering; CUNY Energy Institute)
          Co-PI: Joel Koplik (Prof. of Physics; Levich Institute)

 

International Collaborating Institutions:

Norway: SINTEF, NTNU, University of Oslo

France: INP-ENSIACET, INRAE, LCPQ, ENSTA ParisTech,

Germany: KIT, University of Hamburg, Fraunhofer UMSICHT, Fraunhofer ISE, Leibniz Institut für Polymerforschung Dresden e.V. (IPF)

Funding Partner Agencies: Research Council of Norway, CNRS (France), DFG (Germany) 

PROJECT OVERVIEW

This PIRE project was aimed at accelerating research, education and training in multi-phase fluid engineering science and developing a diverse STEM workforce through international collaboration with twelve institutions in three European countries. The research focused on molecular and interfacial phenomena in multiphase fluids containing liquids and solids with a goal to improve energy and process efficiency in industrial systems such as oil & gas, thermal energy storage, and environmentally friendly refrigeration.

Four Research Thrusts were set up involving complex multi-phase fluids: i) Asphaltene Adsorption, ii) Gas Hydrate Slurries, iii) Drilling Fluids, and iv) Phase-Change-Material Nanoemulsions. In addition, a Modeling group developed advanced numerical simulation techniques to study some of the above phenomena. The four Research Thrusts and Modeling group involved a total of 11 PhD students at City College of New York. Many of them were from minority groups and female, and spent between 3 and 12 months on internships in Norway, France or Germany. A total of 9 PhD students graduated and have obtained employment in industry. In addition, 4 Master’s and 4 undergraduate students as well as two high school students were involved in laboratory research, project management or computer applications.

All four Research Thrusts had a common theme schematically illustrated in Fig. 1. The formation of network structures in multi-phase fluids could have either deleterious or beneficial effects on their properties. To investigate these phenomena up from the atomic length scale to macroscale, cutting-edge experimental and theoretical techniques were used. The multinational research team was composed of experts with proven track records in the development and application of many of these advanced methods.

Unifying Strategy

All four Research Thrusts tackled complicated natural or engineered systems of industrial relevance. The unifying strategy among them is summarized in Fig. 2: the complexity of the system was studied and subsequently reduced to a model system that would capture the relevant physics and chemistry. This model system would then be studied in detail yielding improved multi-scale understanding of the original system. In addition, efforts were made on controlling the formation of network structures, emphasizing actions that can be practically and economically realized.

Computational Methods.

In order to better understand the molecular to macroscopic phenomena of interest, the Modeling group made use of several techniques, each relevant to processes at different length scales or to different material configurations: classical Molecular Dynamics and the Lattice Boltzmann Method (LBM).

MAJOR OUTCOMES

Major findings obtained in this PIRE project have been published in 25 journal papers and 9 Ph.D. theses. For example, in the Phase Change Material (PCM) Nanoemulsions Thrust, the molecular origins of phase instability in PCM nanoemulsions for thermal energy storage were revealed, in part, by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. The molecules that stabilize the nanoemulsions at the oil-water interface were shown to undergo unexpected changes in their environments and dynamics as the oil was frozen and cooled, the process by which the emulsions store thermal energy. NMR enabled the amount of oil to be quantified non-invasively, yielding new insights into a deleterious process called supercooling that reduces efficiency. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) methods revealed that flow instabilities occur when the oil phase melts, which at higher shear rates can be irreversible.

            In the Drilling Fluids Thrust, the mechanism of heavy particle sedimentation was investigated by using an experimental apparatus simulating a drilling operation in an oil/gas wellbore. Transparent model fluids such as a Carbomer solution with similar properties as the opaque drilling fluids were first developed to enable the use of advanced flow visualization techniques. By using a Taylor-Couette cell with a rotating liquid flow, the forces acting on small solid particles such as rock cuttings and heavy weighting agents (e.g., Barite particles) were identified. These findings would be useful for optimizing the composition and use of drilling fluids in the oil and gas industry.
